comments.commentBody:
What, no mention of "the one" in this?
Why am I not surprised.
This should be all Putin needs to that the eastern part of Ukraine, because if its good for the goose its good for the gander!
Whaddya talkin' about? GWB couldn't tie his velcro running shoes without DIck Cheney leading him astray with all his Bravo Sierra gravitas... puh-leez
Do they need to attack or declare war?
We have tried the peaceful road but discovered that most other countries do not share that value.
That was funny. Slick too, if it weren't the lie that Bush Sr. propaganda machine used to rally Americans to Desert Storm.
Well, it will be interesting to see how well we can "manage" over 30,000 terrorists with air strikes.

Eichmann may be the personification of evil, but Arendt's point is that any number of people could thus be singled out.  The Banality of Evil arises from the complicity of a multitude of individuals who have the potential to do otherwise but instead enable the perpetration of evil. ("Evil in the Third Reich had lost the quality by which most people recognize it - the quality of temptation.  Many...must have been tempted not...to become accomplices....But God knows, they had learned how to resist temptation." - Chapter VIII). Our saving grace comes from the likes of Anton Schmidt - a German soldier executed for helping the Jewish resistance in Poland (Chapter XIV).  His story is for Arendt the antithesis of Eichmann's and relieves her - and all of us - from utter despair in the face of evil. "For the lesson of such stories is simple and within everybody's grasp.  Politically speaking. it is that under conditions of terror most people will comply but some people will not...Humanly speaking, no more is required, and no more can reasonably be asked, for this planet to remain fit for human habitation."
"Forced-birthers", yes, that's what they are. I will use that term from now on.

The IS now has what it has been pushing for -- a U.S. led attack directed against it, with support from a whole range of Sunni states that the IS sees as corrupt and ready for regime change. U.S. leadership guarantees that there will be a steady stream of recruits for the IS, and a long unconventional war throughout the Sunni Arab world. Syria-Iraq are only the starting points of the Caliphate. Jordan, the Arabian peninsula, and Egypt all have regimes which embrace (for their elites) Western materialism. concentrating those goodies of capitalism in the hands of the few. Totalitarian Islam is a populist response to the failure of modernization to make the lives of most people desirable. The Arab Spring was the last great hope. The Egyptian military never lost power, and Morsi failed to reach out beyond the Muslim Brotherhood's small business and rural base. The fight for the Arab world is complicated by the IS commitment to sectarian war against Shia Islam. That may re-ignite conflict in places like Lebanon. Now the long fight begins.
GWB took many actions starting with Iraq....Who then were marching and chanting...

It's been years since a major piece of legislation was passed, but the Supreme Court has been relentlessly eliminating laws that once protected the American democracy. Its Citizens United ruling of January, 2010, for instance, handed all three branches of the federal government over to the Koch brothers.

Nit picking, I guess, but the point about no major legislation being passed is not truly an issue.  Who cares if legislation is major or minor, and who decides?  Sometimes a modest approach to a set of problems can be effective.  What is not effective is no action, repeated mindless votes to repeal the ACA, extended vacations and fewer work days than any one else in this country with a job -- in short, a do-nothing Congress, which has clearly frustrated and blocked a president -- as it would any president.

Thank goodness there was a bottleneck to restrain President Obama and his party.  If only the GOP had been more of an obstacle, then somebody, anybody, might have read the ObamaCare bill before it was voted on.

"We don’t suffer from an abuse of power as much as a nonuse of power. It’s been years since a major piece of legislation was passed, and there’s little prospect that one will get passed in the next two.

This leadership crisis is eminently solvable"

Yeah, it sure is... Vote out the GOP. That's where the bottleneck has been since 2010.

Jim,

This means I posted data here at DE, which was found at c3, not that I posted on c3, which I cannot do, as I am not a party to their website or operation. Is this clear enough for you?

Do what I do.. I invest in the market of "arms"
You be making a "killing" and you wont be here complaining my friend..

The happiest man in the world tonight is Bashar al-Assad. His enemies in the world are attacking one of his enemies at home, ISIS, freeing him to focus on his other enemies at home, al-Nusra, the Syrian Free Army, and other anti-government rebels.

It's going to be tricky to deflate ISIS without empowering Assad, and we may or may not succeed. But we have to try.

politicsbyeccehomo.wordpress.com

Yes, ISIS is a medieval and cruel force but, might we ask what is the legal platform supporting this action? Is it simply "because we can?" Even George Bush knew that he had to have the imprimatur of the UN. Otherwise, next time Russia finds "terrorists" in Ukraine, China finds "separatists" in Tibet, and Syria "guerrillas" in Lebanon, just for an example, those countries, regardless of merit will too say "we can do it because we can, after all the US did it".

A military action over a sovereign territory must be at least partially sanctioned by international law --because, like it or not, going to the trouble of a UN resolution protects our allies and democracies from the work of tyrants.

Subverting international law, and bypassing the UN, even if for good cause, is bound to haunt us back, and result in even more war and strife.

Go in big. End it quick. No nation building.

Make an example of another tribe while you're at it. Yemen and Somalia, and suddenly have Iran's nuclear plant cause a leak, poisoning the water for the IRG and top leaders.

Make it so in a few years the view of Islam is "we'll never do that again. What were we thinking?"
That's the general idea.

We just don't seem to learn. One of the biggest failures in Viet Nam was the thought that air superiority could win the war. These new/old enemies....whatever their names may be and there are many..... are just as dedicated and just as tough in an equally forbidding terrain. A difference is they are driven by something much deeper than the VN; religion. They are fighting a holy war.

It is a dream to think wars can be won by conventional air delivery. It is also a dream to think we can continue to train combatants to fight in place of our troops and give them our weapons. Again, look to Viet Nam. Look to our experience in Afghanistan, and the Russians. We just don't learn.

Our leadership, and I am hesitant to call it that, has to get beyond dreams, hope and deal with reality. The reality that we can't fight every war that comes down the road, but we better fight with all we have when we do.

For this action to be effective, it must be massive with no letup. There will be collateral damage. Probably, lots of collateral damage. This will sound brutal because it is, but it has to be followed up with low altitude helicopter gunships that target people. The buildings are the first stage. Then go after the ISIS fighters, one at a time.

If they can be devastated from the air, then maybe it will be possible to somehow find one or two Iraqi divisions that will march in and hold the ground. Ground troops from some source will have to march in. No way around it.

Whether or not this campaign helps Assad is irrelevant at this stage. He is also a cancer. Since we have made the decision to violate Syria's sovereign space, then what's the difference in targeting his butchers?

For whatever reason, be it a failing of Obama foreign policy, or conditions and events that we could not control, both Iraq and Syria have ceased to exist as we knew them or thought we new them.

After the 2003 invasion, we made every mistake possible that would guarantee Iraq's decent into chaos. We and the rest of the world stood by and let Syria descend into chaos. Once we get rid of the ISIS cancer, there will be a chance to rebuild the area into something resembling stability. But we can't do that. The surrounding nations must be involved. The proxy wars must stop, funding of terrorists must stop. Borders must be redrawn respecting ethnicity. Otherwise, it will all happen again.

There are many skeptics of the current course of action. They're perfectly reasonable in their skepticism. Yes, American involvement in the Middle East is most of the time a recipe for disaster (there are counter-examples--Look at the Kurds in Iraq, who owe their relative prosperity and their political freedom to American support), but inaction could be worse than anything we do now.

ISIS is the greatest threat to the Middle East right now, and it's quite clear that the local governments don't have the power or will to defeat it. The idea of the Syrian Government defeating ISIS is a pipe dream, and even if they could their actions against their own people put them in the same moral category, they just put on cologne every morning before going to work.

Obama is a warmonger just like the one before him. Does anyone really believe its just about ISIS? The Pentagon wanted Assad gone last year. The American people said no. And from out of the blue comes a really scary, super, super, evil bunch of terrorists which causes support for military action to skyrocket. So what's the plan? Arm the Syrian rebels to the teeth and setup bombing runs on ISIS as the first step to pivot the war into Syria. Does anyone really think the rebels are going to help us fight ISIS and not expect us to overthrow Assad for them? Or once ISIS is vanquished that the US won't just keep going until Assad is overthrown. Wake up folks, we've seen this movie before. Obama is just the slim head on the pig of US foreign policy.

It is being done, if you'd read the news you'd know it. EU and US are working on choking off the financing and transport of oil. Bombing expensive infrastructure should be avoided. That's why the dams weren't bombed, but taken with ground forces.
I do read the news, and I haven't seen anything.

It's very easy now, especially with the Turkish hostages freed, to disrupt and shut down the Islamic State's oil operations and deprive them of much needed cash.  Why isn't this being done?  Has someone lobbied to keep the oil infrastructure intact and safe?
If the president succeeds in ending ISIS, he truly would deserve a Nobel Peace Prize.
Judging by your comment, Shane, I take it you make a good living these days.

You know why this would never happen to me? Because I have the good sense....oops nope....make that to not face the situation. Yes I'm fortunate enough to have the money that I can pay for doctors and overnight visits.  This loving mother is really being thrown in a form of debtors prison. Anyone connected with doing this to her should be deeply ashamed.

It would be ever so much more reassuring if our "Arab allies" -- whose sheikhs' sons are having a better-than-your-average-video-game experience piloting their attack aircraft against sitting ducks -- actually took just one truly meaningful step:  Stopped their own wealthy extremists from funding terrorists.
So...we should just sit back and let them slaughter us and our allies?
